# 典型题目分析

本次绿色指标英语学科测试主要考查了学生“听力”“语法词汇”“阅读”和“写作”四个方面的状况。

听的考查含有四个部分。Section A主要考查学生是否能听懂句子，识别相关话题语汇，选择相匹配的图片；Section B主要考查学生是否能听懂句子，根据语言功能，选择相应的应答；Section C主要考查学生是否能够听懂日常生活中的简短对话，选择相应的答案。Section D主要考查学生是否具有在听的过程中理解并抓住关键信息以及正确记录该信息的能力。

语言知识的考查含有三个部分。Section A主要考查学生是否能够在简单语境中，根据语法和词汇知识选择相应的答案。Section B主要考查学生是否能够判断句子所缺词汇的词性，根据词义和词形变化选择恰当的单词或短语。Section C主要考查学生是否能够运用词形变化和简单的构词法知识，填入恰当的单词。

阅读的考查含有三个部分。Section A主要考查学生在图片的帮助下，是否能读懂简单的句子，并选择相应的图片；Section B主要考查学生是否能够运用阅读技能，读懂连续性和非连续性文本，选择恰当的答案。Section C主要考查学生是否能够读懂文本，根据语境选择恰当的词汇，补全所缺内容。

写作考查含有一个任务。主要考查学生在图片和文字提示下短文写作能力。

以下选择4个考查维度中的若干道试题，分别对“听力”“语法词汇”“阅读”和“写作”四个维度进行典型题的分析。

\questiontitle{Task 2 Look, listen and match} \\
W: Good morning. John Locke Travel Service. Can I help you? \\ 	
M: Yes. I’d like to go to Paris. \\
W: Certainly. Could I have your name please, sir?  \\
M: Mike Charles.  \\
W: Thank you. Now when would you like to travel, Mike?  \\
M: I have to be in Paris on the eleventh of March, so I’d like to leave on the ninth. Can you do that? \\
W: Certainly, sir, and when do you want to return?  \\
M: Three and a half months later, on the thirtieth of June. I must be back here in July.  \\
W: OK. One moment, Mike. I can book for you now.  \\
M: Good. How much will it cost?  \\
W: Three hundred and sixty-five pounds—that’s special price for business travellers. \\
M: That’s fine. \\
W: Will you drive your car to the airport or go by taxi? \\
M: I’ll take the train. Can you get me a ticket for that too? \\
W: Yes, of course, sir. \\
\hline
\end{longtable}

query2.plot.bar.district.en.question.E8AS18111

学生作答这个题目需要根据文本

\begin{longtable}{|p{14cm}|} \hline
  ...so I’d like to leave on the ninth. \\  \hline
\end{longtable}
\setcounter{table}{\value{table}-1}

直接获取信息，填入9/9th/ninth。只有`r gio.R$VarTierSamKey(query2.data, "E8AS18111_X", "区","总体","2")`％的学生能够完成本题任务，错误原因是ninth 拼写错误。更多的同学是提取了干扰信息：

\begin{longtable}{|p{14cm}|} \hline
I have to be in Paris on the eleventh of March ...\\ \hline
\end{longtable}
\setcounter{table}{\value{table}-1}

而填写了11/11th/eleventh。

\questiontitle{典型题目}20：E8AO70111

\begin{itshape}
It’s seven o’clock in the morning. Tom Martin’s wife gets ready for work. Tom stays at home with his children, Billy, aged two years, and Eve, aged two months.

About 1.4 million fathers in the U.S. stay at home to take care of their children. Tom, 38, is one of them. His wife Carol works for a construction company. After two years at home with their babies, she’s happy to be back at work.

Tom, Billy, and Eve have breakfast together. Then they look at picture books or Tom and Billy play ball games in the park. Every day at eleven, Tom takes Billy to preschool for two hours. Then he goes back home with Eve and works for an hour or two while the baby sleeps. Tom is a programmer, so it is easy to work at home.

Sharon Rivers, a preschool teacher, says, “This situation is quite normal these days. In some families, the mum takes care of the children, but in many families, it’s the dad. Some fathers want to stay at home and take care of their children; some fathers stay at home because their wife makes more money. The important thing is that they all love their children.” When Carol comes home from work, Tom goes out for a game of tennis. In the evening, the family has dinner together. Billy and Eve go to bed at eight, and then Carol and Tom can relax together and talk about their day.

So, what is Tom’s advice to young fathers? “We have about fifty years to work and make money, but only a few years to watch our babies grow. Don’t miss this important time.”

Which of the following statements is right?

[A] Both Billy and Eve are two years old.

[B] Carol and Tom can relax together before 8 o’clock every day.

[C] Carol stayed at home for two years before she went back to work.

[D] Every day, when Billy and Eve sleep, Tom works for about two hours.

\end{itshape}

\questiontitle{典型题目}21、22、23：E8AO71111、E8AO72111、E8AO74111

\begin{itshape}

My grandma picks me up after school. She takes care of me while my parents are at work. Grandma is always interested in my homework.

Today, I had to use the computer to do my homework. First, I went on the Internet to find out about how bears live in the winter. Then I typed up a report. Grandma said, “Such progress!” I asked her what she had meant. She told me about how computers have changed everything. “Computers have even changed the way kids do homework,” she said.
Grandma told me that when she was a girl, people did not have computers at home.

“Well, how did you look up information?” I asked Grandma. She told me that she went to the library and read books about the information she needed to learn. If she needed help with homework, she asked her mother. Her mum was at home every day.

When my parents come home, I will be excited to tell them what Grandma said. Things sure have changed since Grandma was a girl!
\end{itshape}

[D] Grandma helped me with my school project about bears.
